body: A suspect in the killing of a bystander on a Brooklyn street this month is fighting extradition back to New York from Georgia, where he was arrested on Sunday. The man, Darius Dubarry, 27, of Brooklyn, said at a hearing in the Magistrate Court of Richmond County in Augusta that he would not waive extradition, said Daniel J. Craig, the Augusta
title: Suspect in Bystander's Killing Fights to Block Extradition

body: Firefighters crawled beneath flames to pull a critically burned 3-year-old girl from a house fire in Brooklyn on Thursday night, the Fire Department said. The girl, whose name was not released, sustained serious burns over 70 percent of her body and was taken to the burn center at NewYork-Presbyterian Hospital/Weill Cornell Medical Center in
title: Girl, 3, Burned in Brooklyn Blaze

body: Every new police officer in New York City will be sent onto the streets of some of the city's toughest neighborhoods as part of a broad anticrime operation that the authorities say has helped produce historic drops in crime, the city announced on Wednesday. Police officials and Mayor Michael R. Bloomberg said that each of the 914 police recruits
title: CITY IS DOUBLING POLICE PROGRAM TO REDUCE CRIME

body: St. John's forward Rob Thomas scored his first college basket last week. It came nearly 5,000 miles away, in an empty gymnasium during a Red Storm loss at a tournament in Hawaii. The remote setting proved a fitting backdrop. His 12-foot jumper came after a long, lonely journey just to reach the court. Thomas overcame a childhood of poverty in
title: Two Kinds of Comebacks For a St. John's Freshman

body: A man sought in the killing of an apparent bystander on a Brooklyn street on Dec. 15 was arrested Sunday morning in a motel room in Augusta, Ga., the New York City police said. The man, Darius Dubarry, 27, of Brooklyn, is expected to be charged in the shooting death in Crown Heights of Carol Simon-Hayes, said Detective John Sweeney, a police
title: Arrest in Georgia In the Slaying Of a Bystander

body: Stacks of plastic bags line a wall of Joanne Sawyer's front room. From the jumble of her belongings, she pulls out a child-size pink chair, and bursts into tears. The chair is for her young granddaughters, and it is missing a leg. ''I'm not going to throw it away,'' Ms. Sawyer says. ''We'll find it.'' The chair leg is one of a thousand things that
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Mourning Many Losses, Rebuilding a Sense of Home

body: ''You just have to be careful,'' said Jeffrey Watler, wearing a winter coat over the collared shirt required by his employer, a messenger service. Knapsack on his back, he threaded his way through pedestrians, bike messengers and dogs on the way to his next pickup near Grand Central Terminal. For Mr. Watler, 25, who walks with an impaired gait and
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Facing Treacherous Streets With Limited Mobility

body: St.Clair Bourne, a documentary filmmaker who recorded American black culture, produced portraits of eminent African-Americans and, in one stark film, drew a parallel between the civil rights movement and the ''troubles'' in Northern Ireland, died on Saturday in Manhattan. He was 64 and lived in Brooklyn. The cause was a pulmonary embolism, said
title: St.Clair Bourne, Filmmaker, Dies at 64

body: IT was tough for Talima Davis, Brooklyn born and bred, to leave her beloved borough. ''My friends call me the quintessential Brooklyn girl,'' she said. ''I never leave Brooklyn except to go to work.'' But when she found herself priced out of even Bedford-Stuyvesant, she decided she had no choice. When she was growing up, Ms. Davis, 27, lived with
title: THE HUNT; Leaving Brooklyn

author: More Dispatches: nytimes.com/cityroom
body: GABOUREY SIDIBE, from Bedford-Stuyvesant and later Harlem, had seen bright lights and dressing rooms. She had been backstage at the Apollo. Her mother, Alice Tan Ridley, is a singer, and Gabbie, as people now call her, sometimes felt as if she and her brother had grown up behind the bar at the Cotton Club. She had done some singing, too, and had
title: DISPATCHES; The Audition That Left Them Speechless

body: In the six years since he received help from The New York Times Neediest Cases Fund, Florent Mathurin has scrambled and saved his way into a new life, which he suddenly seems in danger of losing. ''It's a long journey and it's a far walk I have done, from where I was to where I'm at now,'' Mr. Mathurin said. Mr. Mathurin, 45, spent 10 years
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; After Coming So Far, He Stands to Lose So Much

body: ''THE Last Man on Earth Is Not Alone,'' proclaims the advertising for ''I Am Legend,'' the Will Smith apocalyptic thriller opening Friday. It's true: Mr. Smith's character, Robert Neville, and his trusty German shepherd are surrounded by terrifying creatures. But they're not zombies; they're just infected with a man-made virus. If you could see
title: Hollywood Windfall? Take It to the Streets

author: Leslie Kaufman contributed reporting.
body: A 33-year-old Brooklyn man was charged yesterday with killing his 3-year-old daughter, who died Wednesday night after being beaten and severely burned, officials said. The girl's father, Jason Marcelle, of 350 Marcus Garvey Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant, was charged with second-degree murder, manslaughter and endangering the welfare of a child,
title: Father in Brooklyn Is Held in Beating Death of Girl, 3

title: Art in Review

body: The death of a 3-year-old girl late Wednesday in Bedford-Stuyvesant was ruled a homicide yesterday by the city medical examiner. Police investigators were questioning the girl's parents, and her three siblings were placed with the Administration for Children's Services. The police said they found the girl, identified as Tkai Marcelle, unconscious
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Girl's Death Ruled Homicide

body: When Elton Rodriguez, then 14, finally found the courage to ask Kiara Nieves to the John Ericsson Junior High School prom in Williamsburg, Brooklyn, it was a week before the dance in June. Kiara's enthusiastic ''Yes!'' came with a condition: He had to ask her mother, Alexa Pacheco, for permission. ''I'm strict,'' said Ms. Pacheco, sitting next to
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; Teenager Had a Date to the Prom, but How to Pay for a Dress?

body: Two brothers were shot, one fatally, in an argument with other men early yesterday outside a restaurant and bar near Columbia University as the wounded man tried to shield his younger brother from gunfire, the police and the men's mother said. The wounded brother, Stephone Jones, 26, of Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn, told his mother that he believed
title: Two Brothers Are Shot, One of Them Fatally, Outside Bar Near Columbia Campus

author: As told to Louise Kramer.
body: WHEN I said I was going to become an exterminator, everybody laughed at me. They thought I was nuts. It was 1987, the year of the crash. I worked on Wall Street in commodities and I could see the writing on the wall. People were being laid off. My wife was pregnant, and I told her I had to find something else to do. One day an exterminator came to
title: PREOCCUPATIONS; When Opportunity Came Crawling

body: FOR at least 13 years, neighbors say, the overgrown land behind the ShopRite parking lot in Borough Park, Brooklyn, has been a headache. Among many complaints made to the city, they pointed in 1994 to fire damage to an old warehouse at the site, in 1998 to the danger that the warehouse roof would collapse, and, just this fall, to homeless people
title: BOROUGH PARK; On an Unloved Lot, A New Source of Friction

body: Despite a court order, a police detective has repeatedly failed to show up to give a deposition in a Brooklyn man's lawsuit charging police brutality. Now the city says the detective has retired and cannot be found, an explanation that has failed to satisfy the judge overseeing the case. In a photograph, a bruised bump rises to the size of a small
title: Detective Misses 5 Calls To Testify In Beating

body: A blood-streaked, shirtless man wanted for stabbing a roommate was killed in a hail of gunfire by two police officers on a Brooklyn street yesterday when, the police said, he brandished a broken wine bottle, advanced on them as they backed away, ignored their orders to drop it and finally lunged at them. In a face-off witnessed by two other
title: Police Kill a Man Armed With a Broken Bottle

body: John L. Phillips Jr. took a seat in the last row of the theater and surveyed its crumbling ceiling, the debris strewn in the aisles and the faded art that he had hung a generation ago. ''Hardy!'' Mr. Phillips, 83, called out to Clarence Hardy, his assistant and friend, who was down the aisle a bit. ''Quite a place, isn't it? We ought to think about
title: Faded Dreams and a Lost Fortune

body: It was done after three men were shot in Queens a year ago in a hail of 50 police bullets. It occurred again on Monday, after five officers fired 20 shots at Khiel Coppin outside his Brooklyn home, killing him. A man is down, on the ground, bleeding, and the police are handcuffing him. Relatives, friends, neighbors and curious onlookers often see
title: Handcuffing the Wounded: A Police Tactic Hits a Raw Nerve

body: None of the five officers who fired 20 bullets in Monday's fatal shooting of a troubled 18-year-old man in Brooklyn had ever shot at a person before in a combined 62 years of police service, law enforcement officials said yesterday. Two of the officers fired to defend themselves from pit bulls in three separate confrontations. One, a sergeant who
title: 5 Officers Who Killed Man Never Shot Anyone Before

body: As the last chaotic day of Khiel Coppin's life unfolded on Monday, an unmarked white sport utility vehicle arrived at his home on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. Out came a team of crisis counselors from Interfaith Medical Center, a hospital about a mile away. Mr. Coppin was not there, having left the apartment earlier. The counselors
title: Police Shooting Puts Focus On Mental Crisis Teams

body: It was a familiar exchange of pleasantries. Denise Owens would wheel her cart into the C-Town Supermarket across the street from her grim apartment complex on Gates Avenue in Bedford-Stuyvesant. Alan Dorsette, 15, a cashier at the store who lived down the hall from her, would ask, ''How's your son?'' Sometimes Ms. Owens would say ''He's O.K.'' More
title: Before Shooting in Brooklyn, a History of Mental Illness and Family Discord

body: A troubled 18-year-old man. A furious family argument inside a first-floor Brooklyn apartment. A 911 call. Then, in the darkness, 20 bullets fired by five police officers. The 18-year-old is fatally wounded. The police say he was holding a hairbrush. The episode unfolded in about 14 minutes in the apartment, an alley next to it and the sidewalk in
title: Commissioner Defends 'Tragic' Shooting as Within Police Guidelines

body: A young man was fatally shot last night in a hail of 20 bullets fired by five police officers who responded to his mother's 911 call for help in a domestic dispute in Brooklyn, the authorities said. The police said they believed that the man, Khiel Coppin, 18, had a gun. But when the gunfire stopped, it turned out that he had been holding a
title: Man, 18, Is Fatally Shot by Police in Brooklyn

body: Sabrina Conney twisted her hand into a C chord and smiled toward the polished surface of her guitar. ''I don't know what to call this,'' she said. ''Country? Sounds like country to me.'' Ms. Conney's voice whispered low above the deep thrum of the strings, relating the tale of someone spotted across a room, the courage to approach, to talk. ''I saw
title: THE NEEDIEST CASES; As Paranoia Fades, Confidence and Music Thrive

body: MICHAEL ANDALORO lived in Alphabet City for nearly 25 years before moving to Brooklyn last year, and he doesn't long for Manhattan. ''I didn't miss it for the past 10 years,'' Mr. Andaloro said facetiously. The bohemian East Village of his younger days had become so bourgeois that he could barely recognize it. ''On Thursday nights, it was like
title: HABITATS | BEDFORD-STUYVESANT, BROOKLYN; Rediscovering New York As It Used to Be

title: Jazz Listings

body: A 14-year-old boy was fatally shot shortly before 7 o'clock last night in the lobby of a public housing complex in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Sunny Carter, was shot several times at 85 Tompkins Avenue, part of Tompkins Houses, where he lived in another building. He was taken to Woodhull Medical and Mental Health Center and was
title: NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Teenager Shot To Death

body: Taken as a young child from her drug-abusing mother, the girl had lived in one foster home after another. Now, at 16, she saw the day approaching when she would become an adult and be sent off to make a life on her own. She desperately wanted to be ready, and one last bit of help seemed to be at hand. New York City had paid her foster care agency,
title: A HISTORY OF NEGLECT; City Is Slow to Limit Damage As a Hope for Children Fails

body: The City Council approved rezoning 206 blocks of Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, moving to protect the historic charm that has attracted a flood of new residents to the area and to spur economic development and the construction of low-cost housing along major thoroughfares. The Brooklyn rezoning came as the Council also approved creating the largest
title: Action on Development In Brooklyn and Queens

body: ''How many of you guys got a hooptee, raise your hand?'' Carlos Caraballo asked his senior auto shop at Automotive High School in Brooklyn. A dozen boys, roughly half the class, raised their hands and began discussing their hooptees. The term is street slang for a cheap, functional car favored by city youths who often tinker tirelessly to make the
title: A High School Under the Hood

body: WHILE hunting for a new home, Ethan Benton had two familiar priorities -- larger space and lower rent. He spent nearly six years in an East Village apartment shared with three roommates, where his bedroom measured 7 feet by 9 feet. Beneath his loft bed, he crammed several bicycles, assorted bicycle parts, a dresser, a computer and supplies for his
title: THE HUNT; No Roommates, Lots of Bikes

author: Joyce Johnson is the author of the memoirs ''Minor Characters'' and ''Missing Men.''

title: Passing Strange

body: On a recent weekday at the BedStuy Campaign Against Hunger, one of Brooklyn's largest food pantries, shelves that are usually piled high with staples like rice and canned meats were empty, a stark illustration of the crisis facing emergency food providers across the city. The Brooklyn organization is among about 1,000 food pantries and soup
title: Distressing Trends for Food Banks: More Clients, Fewer Supplies

body: THE Brooklyn real estate market has turned into a bundle of contradictions in recent months. While prices in neighborhoods like Park Slope and Brooklyn Heights soared this summer, so did the number of foreclosures in neighborhoods like Bushwick and Bedford-Stuyvesant. Sorting through these contradictions, buyers are starting to find bargains in a
title: Brooklyn: A Bargain Hunter's Guide

title: Calendar

body: Declining prices, rising inventory and increasing foreclosure rates may have hobbled many of the nation's housing markets, but they have not yet reached Manhattan and brownstone Brooklyn. The people who closed on co-ops, condominiums and town houses there paid more than ever, on average, for real estate in the third quarter of this year. Four
title: Home Prices Buck Trend, For Now

title: Footnotes

title: Brooklyn Could Get a High School for Marketers

The album, which his label plans to release in early November, came together over the past few weeks
title: For Jay-Z, Inspiration Arrives in a Movie

title: Before Gentrification Was Cool, It Was a Movie

I know I want communications and journalism, but I haven't found a perfect match yet. I want to go to college to experience new things and meet new people. But it's kind of scary to decide about your future.'' Jill Feigelman St.

body: NOT everyone who works in the Steve's C-Town supermarket, on Ninth Street near Fifth Avenue in Park Slope, is a teenager. It can, however, seem that way to a customer, waiting in the long express line that curves toward the seltzer display and the frozen foods while the stock boys flirt with the cash register girls, the delivery guys lounge out
title: PIN MONEY; Angst Amid the Artichokes

body: Two newspaper reporters described by prosecutors as critical to a murder case against the parents of the 7-year-old victim cannot be compelled to testify, a judge ruled yesterday. The mother, Nixzaliz Santiago, 29, and the stepfather, Cesar Rodriguez, 28, have been charged with failing to render medical help to the child, Nixzmary Brown, who was
title: Reporters Won't Have to Testify in Death

body: IF asked to name a young American director who made his mark in the early 1990s, who gravitates toward criminal underworlds and loves movies with the passion of a geek, most people would say Quentin Tarantino. But there is another, less obvious answer: James Gray, who directed his first feature, ''Little Odessa,'' when he was 24 and in many ways
title: An Auteur For a Neglected New York City

body: The four-faced clock atop the 512-foot-tall Williamsburgh Savings Bank building, not far from the Brooklyn Academy of Music, is the neighborhood's pride -- and sometimes its despair. Its 27-foot-wide faces have occasionally broadcast times that differ not merely from the actual hour but also from one another. One victim of these foibles may have
title: BROOKLYN UP CLOSE; The Clock That Vanished

body: In the world of museums and galleries, the British artist Mike Nelson is highly respected: he was recently included for a second time on the shortlist for the Turner Prize, whose winner is to be announced in December. People tend to return Mr. Nelson's calls. They show up for meetings with him. But in the other world he has inhabited, just as long
title: Belonging and Belief, Found in Scrap Lumber

body: Marcia V. Lyles, New York City's new deputy chancellor for teaching and learning, knows intimately just how students can get lost in the shuffle. In her sophomore year in high school in Harlem, Ms. Lyles was caught skipping class almost daily. ''I knew how to cut, who to cut, where to cut,'' Ms. Lyles, 58, said in a recent interview, her
title: FACE BOOK; A New Role, but for Her, Familiar Turf

body: After a year and a half of legal maneuvers and pretrial motions, murder charges against the parents of 7-year-old Nixzmary Brown now hang on their own words, a judge said yesterday. ''Trust me,'' said the judge, L. Priscilla Hall of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, speaking from the bench, ''this is basically a statement case.'' But while many
title: Prosecutors Seek Reporters' Testimony in Murder Case Against Couple

body: MAYA ARULPRAGASAM'S Brooklyn apartment was a neglected mess when she finally returned to it last month after six months abroad. But it took only a day to straighten it up and turn it into her version of a pied-à-terre, a makeshift multimedia headquarters. An audio mixing board, film canisters and shiny gold and black dancing outfits stood on one
title: MUSIC; An Itinerant Refugee in a Hip-Hop World

body: Sitting in a narrow dressing room behind a heavy red curtain at the Birdland jazz club in Midtown, the saxophonist James Moody, 82, rested his head in his hand and remembered gigs with Dizzy Gillespie, Thelonious Monk and someone else: Max Roach, his longtime friend, the legendary jazz drummer who died on Thursday at age 83. It had been quite some
title: Beat Goes On in Clubs, Minus a Bebop Virtuoso

body: Max Roach, a founder of modern jazz who rewrote the rules of drumming in the 1940s and spent the rest of his career breaking musical barriers and defying listeners' expectations, died early yesterday in Manhattan. He was 83. His death, at an undisclosed hospital, was announced by a spokesman for Blue Note Records, Mr. Roach's last label. No cause
title: Max Roach, Master of Modern Jazz, Dies at 83

title: Spare Times

body: The seriousness of what had just happened did not register with Judith Bailey until she looked into a mirror. Layers of skin were peeling off her body. ''My skin was gone,'' she recalled yesterday in an interview from her hospital bed. Ms. Bailey was a passenger in a red tow truck that was tossed into the air and into a crater after a steam pipe
title: Burn Victim's One Thought After Blast: 'Make It Stop'

body: The 11-month-old girl stood in the tub, playing in shallow water with a 2-year-old girl, both looked after by a teenage mother home alone. title: A Baby Girl's Bath Becomes A Young Couple's Nightmare

title: HABITATS | NORTH WILLIAMSBURG, BROOKLYN; The Art Is Striking, And So Are the Cars

body: ASSUMING the worst, Lesley Horton was extra-prepared when she embarked on her apartment hunt last spring. title: THE HUNT; Fully Prepared for Anything

title: Brooklyn Heights; Wanted: A School of Their Own

body: ONE Monday morning, on the way to her office in the basement of the Montauk Club in Park Slope, Louise Crawford passed a man staring up at a tree. Lingering for a moment, she asked him what was so interesting. It turned out that a yellow-throated songbird known as a Nashville warbler, in its northward migration, had made a pit stop in the
title: Cracker-Barrel 2.0

body: DANCE Claudia La Rocco With New York City once again resembling a giant, smelly sauna, a trip to JACOB'S PILLOW is worth it for the change of scenery alone. It's also the only place in the country to see a unique program by DANCERS OF THE ROYAL DANISH BALLET. Led by its current artistic director, Frank Andersen, and joined by its next artistic
title: THE WEEK AHEAD: JULY 8-14; DANCE

body: POP Full reviews of recent concerts: nytimes.com/music. AKON (Sunday) This Senegalese-American crooner, now ubiquitous on the charts as a singer, songwriter and producer, makes his amorous R&B-pop hits explicit without seeming nasty. body: The peaks of the Lower Manhattan skyline loomed across the East River, and lap swimmers at the end of their lanes briefly gazed at them before their flip turns. ''Just the fact that there's a pool floating out in the river is astounding to me,'' said David K. Bromwich, 28, who biked to the pool at 5:30 a.m. yesterday, two hours before the next
title: After Decades of Dashed Hopes, Brooklyn Swimmers Rejoice in a Pool With a View

body: An 11-month-old Brooklyn girl who was plucked unresponsive on Tuesday from a full bathtub, where she had been left alone with a 2-year-old aunt, was placed on life support yesterday, and her mother was charged with reckless endangerment for leaving the children unattended, the police said. The baby, Smiele Ordoñez, was listed in critical condition
title: Mother Of Girl Left in Tub Is Charged

body: A construction crew arrived yesterday at a house in Bedford-Stuyvesant to find a body in a bag in the basement, the police said. The house on Lexington Avenue had been unoccupied for three years, said Elvenia Campbell, the owner of a home next door. ''The house was open that whole time until about a week and a half ago, when finally somebody came
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Body Found In Basement

body: An 11-month-old boy was in critical condition last night after his 18-year-old mother found him submerged and unresponsive in the bathtub of their Bedford-Stuyvesant apartment, the police said. The authorities said the woman told them that she had been bathing her son and a friend's 2-year-old girl in her apartment on Classon Avenue, then walked
title: METRO BRIEFING | NEW YORK; Brooklyn: Baby In Critical Condition

body: How much longer will Sonny Carson cast a shadow over New York politics? At least for a while. Dead though he has been, going on five years, the city has yet to see the last of him, in spirit anyway. That much was clear from a display of street theater yesterday on the steps of City Hall that was straight out of the 1960s, down to ''black power''
title: NYC; Racist Ghost Gets Others To Say It Loud

title: What's On Tonight

body: A DENSELY packed 1,200-acre swath of central Brooklyn, Ocean Hill-Brownsville is not among the neighborhoods to have been swept up in the borough's recent renaissance. Its older housing stock is generally less elegant and well preserved than that in nearby Bedford-Stuyvesant. Its streets are not lined with charming cafes or whimsical boutiques. Its
title: LIVING IN/Ocean Hill-Brownsville, Brooklyn; At Long Last, Developers Show an Interest

body: Mayor Bloomberg's fast-advancing plan to charge drivers $8 to drive in the most congested parts of Manhattan may seem geared mostly toward the suburbanites whom many blame for Manhattan's perpetually snarled weekday traffic. But in fact, most of the drivers who would have to pay the toll are the mayor's own constituents: residents of the city
title: Outside Manhattan, Many Oppose Bloomberg's Traffic Plan

body: ALL the world's a stage, sure, but what might Shakespeare have made of the dramatic possibilities of a Lower East Side parking lot, with cars backing out right into the Capulets' masked ball? Or ''Love's Labour's Lost'' on a stroll through Central Park, as helmeted bicyclists whiz by? The outdoor summer theater season had its unofficial opening on
title: Shakespeare, Naturally

body: Let's say that a company moves out of a New York neighborhood that has borne its name for more than a century. Let's also say that we are talking about the place where the ball drops every New Year's Eve. In this age of naming rights and branding strategies, some people might be eager for a change. How does Durst Square strike you? Fine, just fine,
geo_facet: LONG ACRE SQUARE (NOW TIMES SQUARE, NYC)

author: Jay Jennings is a frequent contributor to the Book Review.
body: OPENING DAY The Story of Jackie Robinson's First Season. By Jonathan Eig. Illustrated. 323 pp. Simon & Schuster. $26. Sports anniversaries pile up with insidious regularity. title: A League of His Own

body: In a racially divisive hearing, the City Council yesterday rejected a measure that would have named a street after Sonny Carson, a radical black activist who more than once described himself as ''antiwhite.'' The Council rejected the amendment in a 25-to-15 vote that was divided along racial lines, as protesters in the balcony hissed at each vote
title: Council Rejects Street Name for Black Activist

body: A 45-year-old woman was found dead in her home at 247 Malcolm X Boulevard in Bedford-Stuyvesant yesterday, the police said. She had been stabbed several times in the neck. The woman, who was not identified, was found by police officers shortly after 11:30 a.m. No arrests had been made yesterday evening, the police said.
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Woman Fatally Stabbed

body: A 22-year-old man was fatally shot yesterday afternoon on a street in Bedford-Stuyvesant, the police said. The victim, Christopher Darns, of Brooklyn, was shot at 3:10 p.m. in front of 866 Madison Street, the police said. There have been no arrests, the police said. JENNIFER 8. LEE
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Shot Dead In Street

body: SHERRI CAUGHMAN prides herself on being the kind of conscientious New Yorker who does her homework before making any major purchases. title: Fighting Off Foreclosure

body: The city agreed yesterday to pay $2 million to the parents of a young man killed in a Brooklyn stairwell, ending a three-year effort to account for the damage done by a single bullet fired by a police officer. title: City to Pay $2 Million to Parents Of Man Fatally Shot by an Officer

body: Two old men in baseball caps sat in two old chairs in front of an old building under a warm sun. title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT JOURNAL; Death Finds a Crack in Life at the Social Club

body: A 31-year-old Bedford-Stuyvesant woman whose body was found by firefighters after a fire broke out in her home early yesterday died of strangulation, the city medical examiner's office said last night, adding that the death had been ruled a homicide. The police said the woman also had puncture wounds to her torso. Firefighters were called to the
title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Firefighters Find Homicide Victim

author: Jocko Weyland is the author of ''The Answer Is Never: A Skateboarder's History of the World.''
body: WHEN is a bicycle not like other bicycles? To begin with, when it has no brakes, or at least no visible brakes, or possibly just a front brake. That means you can't ride this bike very well on your first try, and certainly not very gracefully, easily or safely. The rear cog is bolted directly to the hub, so that whenever the vehicle is in motion,
title: Unstoppable

body: THEY came in sweatshirts and fuzzy slippers, suits and oxfords, seeking chocolate muffins and Cheerios. Some grabbed a yogurt and left. Others lingered. title: A Beautiful Day in the Neighborhood

body: One man was killed and another wounded yesterday when they were shot in a sport utility vehicle in Bedford-Stuyvesant by gunmen who pulled up alongside them and began firing, the police said. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Brooklyn: Man Killed In Shooting

title: NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: CROWN HEIGHTS; The Last Lace-Up

title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: Activist's Name Off Street-Naming List

A bill to be introduced in the City Council today with the Bloomberg administration's
title: City Seeks Broader Power to Fix Troubled Buildings at Landlords' Expense

body: At 11 p.m., with the temperature well below freezing, two teams of men in their 30s possessing varying degrees of athletic prowess played a spirited, if sloppy, game of soccer atop a Hudson River pier. A cold wind blew ball and bodies about in unpredictable ways. The men slipped and shouted and laughed, ignoring the burn of artificial turf on their
title: Too Many Men on the Fields (And Women and Children, Too)

body: An off-duty police lieutenant who shot and killed his unarmed tenant during an argument was found not guilty of criminal charges yesterday evening. ''I feel good,'' the lieutenant, Shamik Walton of the 67th Precinct in Brooklyn, said as he walked out of the state courthouse in Brooklyn. ''I feel vindicated.'' The Police Department will most likely
title: Jury Acquits Police Lieutenant Who Killed Unarmed Tenant

body: In the courtroom where Lt. Shamik Walton is on trial, the charge is manslaughter, the stakes are 15 years in prison and the trouble is his alone. But a separate case is developing in the back row of the courtroom, on the 19th floor of State Supreme Court in Brooklyn. There, lawyers are scribbling notes for a lawsuit against Lieutenant Walton's
title: Officer's Trial in Killing Feeds Case Against City

body: Six years ago, when Laurie Cumbo founded Mocada, a museum that showcases the works of black artists across the diaspora, it was housed on the fourth floor of a church-owned brownstone in Bedford-Stuyvesant, Brooklyn. title: COLLECTIONS; A Museum Grows In Brooklyn

body: SINCE 1904, when a group of Ursuline nuns moved into a fortresslike mansion on the south side of this city to begin New York state's first Catholic college for women, all of the campus's buildings have been clad in granite. title: IN THE REGION / WESTCHESTER; Fitting In on Campus

body: Prosecutors sought yesterday to challenge a psychiatric defense offered by the mother of Nixzmary Brown, a 7-year-old girl who was found beaten and starved to death in her family's Brooklyn apartment in January 2006. If successful, the move could prove to be a deciding factor in a murder case that has drawn an outpouring of grief, called top city
title: Prosecutors Challenge Psychiatric Defense of Mother Charged in Girl's Death

body: The killing of a 20-year-old Queens woman, and the arrest of a man who was under court order to stay away from her, has raised troubling questions for law enforcement and the young woman's family about apparent miscues that preceded the attack. title: After Young Woman's Death, Questions About Missed Chances

body: FIRST came chaos, a neighbor said, then death. title: Metro Briefing | New York: Manhattan: City To Expand Housing Program

title: A Team Feared by Rivals Now Sits Idle, and Angry

title: Officer Denies Knowing Car Was Used in a Shootout

body: DRIVING north on the Palisades Interstate Parkway, it's easy to blow past this town and end up halfway to Rockland County. title: MUSIC; Alpine, N.J., Home of Hip-Hop Royalty

title: Policewoman's Husband Charged in Shooting of Plainclothes Officer

title: Pfizer's Birthplace, Soon Without Pfizer

body: Two off-duty police officers were injured, one of them critically, when three people attacked them early yesterday after a car accident on the West Side of Manhattan, the police said. The officers were driving north on 10th Avenue near West 28th Street in Chelsea shortly before 4 a.m. when their Ford Explorer slid on ice and rear-ended a Nissan
title: Officers Hurt In Attack, 1 Critically

body: Three crumpled dollars and two quarters, tugged from the pocket of a puffy coat on a cold night, brings four hot chicken wings with French fries or fried rice. The most expensive dish on the restaurant's menu is No. 71, the lobster meat chow mein, at $8.95 a quart. The Happy House Chinese takeout restaurant in Bedford-Stuyvesant does not feed the
title: BEDFORD-STUYVESANT JOURNAL; An Unthinkable Crime, Till Someone Thought of It

title: Arts, Briefly; Bloomberg Announces Cultural Plans for New York

body: When William McKinney showed up at church one Sunday more than a decade ago, he said he was open to anything that would help him make a fresh start. At the time, Mr. McKinney was running away from a life he had built and lost in Texas. His first marriage had failed, and after a brief period of homelessness, he had returned to Brooklyn, where he was
title: The Neediest Cases; Finding Faith, and Responsibility, After Making a New Start

body: PEOPLE interested in buying brownstones or town houses should not assume that all of the bargains are gone. Brokers say there are still properties in New York City that cost less than $1 million, but only if buyers are willing to venture into often overlooked neighborhoods and tolerate extensive renovations. ''You can still get a lovely brownstone
title: Finding a Town House for Under a Million

body: WHEN Andrew C. Friedman, a Manhattan architect known for his elaborate (and expensive) classical residences, chose a nondescript little brick and fake-stone building in the Bedford-Stuyvesant neighborhood of Brooklyn to redesign, he already knew the kind of urban couple he imagined there -- and they were very different from his usual clients. No,
title: SKETCH PAD; Designing a Starter Town House With a Twist

body: After the life, or at least the career, of one of New York's finest was imperiled in the line of duty yesterday, police officials and reporters gathered inside a Manhattan hospital, awaiting news from doctors. ''The dog should be able to make a full recovery in a month,'' Dr. Jason Fusco finally assured the crowd. But an operation expected to last
title: Police Dog Is Seriously Injured During Pursuit

body: Nixzmary Brown has been buried nearly a year, but as the criminal prosecution of her parents nears trial after months of missed deadlines and legal maneuvers, the case is stirring new passions. For a pretrial hearing yesterday in State Supreme Court in Brooklyn, the gallery was filled with curious onlookers, off-duty prosecutors, distant relatives
title: Girl Is Dead a Year, and Many Can't Forget

title: For Youths Fresh Out of Jail, a Little Help Staying Out
